subsection_content_2: Earlier this month, an outbreak of H5N1 occurred in the Quang Binh and Hoa Binh Provinces of Vietnam.  A total of 400 birds were destroyed to prevent the spread of the disease.  The source of these outbreaks remains unknown.  Control measures applied include quarantine, movement control, and disinfection, while control measures yet to be applied include screening and zoning to monitor any possible future outbreaks.
subsection_content_4: The Servicio Nacional de Sanidad, Inocuidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria (Senasica) of the United States of Mexico continue their monitoring and sampling of birds in the western state of Jalisco and surrounding areas of Mexico in response to the outbreak of the H7N3 avian influenza virus that was first detected back in June.  To date, 537 production units have been sampled.  A total of 64,498 samples have been taken from farms in the infected area with 44 testing positive for H7N3 isolates.  One wild bird has tested positive according to the report to OIE, but no further details was provided.  Since news of the outbreak in June, 22.3 million birds have been killed to help prevent further spread of the virus.  Additionally, 125.8 million doses of a booster vaccine have been distributed to at risk birds.  Officials hope to cease vaccinations in the next 60-90 days as no new avian flu cases have been reported in the past four weeks.
subsection_content_1: Earlier this week, the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that the H5N1 avian flu virus was detected Zhangjiang, in the province of Guangdong.  Symptoms were first reported on September 11, and since then, 6,300 ducks have died and 14,050 have been infected.  To help reduce the risk of more outbreaks, all poultry in the contaminated area were culled and the area was disinfected.
